### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input:Jan went to the auditorium and listened to the speech. Where might he be? Choices:  A: crowd B: high school C: city D: somewhere E: theater<n>Output:		C: city<n><n>### Solution:<n>```<n>"""<n>    Solution.java<n>    Write your code here. Read input from STDIN. Print output to STDOUT<n>"""<n>class Solution {<n>    public int onePlus2(int num)<n>    {<n>        return num + 2;<n>    }<n>    <n>    public double threeAfter(double num)<n>    { <n>        return num * 3;<n>    }<n><n>    public String findLongestWord(String[] words)<n>    {<n>         String maxWord = "";<n>         int maxLength = 0;<n>         for (String word : words) {<n>             if (word.length() > maxLength) {<n>                 maxLength = word.length();    // length is stored<n>                 maxWord = word;                // saved<n>             }<n>         }<n>         return maxWord;<n>    }<n>}<n><n>```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. Choices:  A: complications B: tiredness C: anger D: trial E: court case<n>Output:		A<n><n>## Converting a String<n><n>Let’s examine a simple string manipulation problem.<n><n>The input function takes a single line of text as a string and outputs the input in ASCII codes<n>The convert function is defined as follows:<n><n>convert(string):<n><n>return(the string’s each character’s ASCII value)<n><n>How many calls to the convert function are necessary to convert the string “Welcome to Coding Interviews”<n>to the following ASCII character array:<n><n>“W”, “e”, “l”, “c”, “o”, “m”, “e”, “, “t”, “o”, “C”,“i”, “n”, “t”, “e”, “r”,“v”,“e”,“e”, “l”,“l”, “, “c”, “o”,”D”, “o”, “r”, “h”<n>?<n><n>Explanation: (Please fill in your own)<n><n>The code “Doe” is 61, and its conversion from ASCII to binary is 10.<n><n>1) We begin counting from the end<n><n>1) The 61 is located in the 6th position from the end. The 6th-digit is 1.<n><n>2) We get to the second iteration of the problem.<n><n>2) The problem “W” is “6” and it is located in the 8th position. We get to the 3rd iteration.<n><n>3) The problem “e” is “5” and is located in the 7th position. We get the 4th iteration.<n><n>4) The problem is “4” and is located in position 6<n>5) The problem is “3” and is located in 5<n>6) “2” is the problem and is in position 4<n>7) “1” is the problem and located in 3<n><n>## Binary Search<n><n>## Binary Search:<n>The output of binary search function returns the index of the first occurrence as the index of the first element in the input array that is<n>greater than the input key.<n><n>Let’s consider this test problem:<n><n>Function:<n>```<n>binarySearch(key, a[n+1]):<n> if (key <= a[0]): return 0<n> if(key >= a[n]): return n+1<n> return

Choices:  A: new york B: big city C: town D: idaho E: shopping mall<n>Output:		E<n>```<n>class Solution:<n>    def candy(self, d: str) -> int:<n>        d = d.replace(" ", "")<n>        s = list(d)<n>        cnt = int(s.count(str(93))-1)<n>        if cnt == 4:<n>            return int(s)<n>        else:<n>            return int("".join(str(i)+"2"+str(i) for i in s))<n>            # print(len(s),sum(s))<n>            # return(sum(s))<n><n>    def combinedAges(self, num: int) -> int:<n><n>        ans = 0<n><n>        if num%6 == 0:<n>            m, y = num//6<n>            ans = y+m*4<n>        else:<n>	        print(5)<n>            m, n = (num + 1)//6<n>            ans=n*(6+m+1)<n><n>        return ans<n><n><n><n>        <n>        <n><n>

")<n>```<n><n>```<n>print(p2 + str(a) + str(b) +str(c))<n>print('What white meat goes well'+ str(a)  +'with potatoes?')<n>```<n><n>```Python<n>b = int(input()) # this is b<n>choice = str(a)<n>d = input().upper()<n>optionB = str(a) +''<n>m = 'None of the ';<n><n>while d!!= 'y':

The two resulting numbers have the same value. Choose which solution produces the smallest number.<n>Output:<n>Explanation:<n>1. If the sum is even, change the digits until the left-most 1 is in between other 0's.<n>Example: 894896 -> 890940<n>2. If the sum is odd, change the digits until 1 is on the right.<n>Example: 63885 -> 162885<n><n>**Note:** The values do not have to be two different numbers, e.g. 46129 and 42196 could be changed to 402196 and 42129, respectively.<n><n>Input:If a company buys a piece of machinery for $240. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input:Why would I want to be exercising? Choices:  A: fatigue B: relaxation C: tiredness D: muscle weakness E: losing weight<n>Output:		A, C, E<n><n>Input:How many 10-foot-wide strips of carpet required to cover a triangular shaped area that measures 15 feet at the base and 30 feet along the sides? Choices: <n><n>Output:B<n><n><n><n>``` <n># Solution:<n>def coderRNN(string):<n>    str_len = len(string)<n>    if(str_len==0):<n>        return "Sorry, no input received"<n>   <n>    if(string[0]==')'):<n>        if(string[1]=='('):<n>            return '()'<n>        return ')'<n>    elif((string == ')') and (string=='))'):<n>        return ''<n>    else:<n>        return 'Sorry, no input expected'<n><n>def coderMLP(strings,charList=list(string.ascii_letters)):<n>    lst = list(chain(*(np.delete(string,0, axis=-1) for string in strings))) # string[0] delete from it and return 1D column list<n><n>    lst = [str if char in charList else float(char) for char in lst]# replace to it and return 1d column list<n><n>    return lst<n><n>def MLPSeq(lst,charList=list("abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz"),n=1):<n>    if len(lst)==1:<n>        return list(lst[0])<n><n>    for i in range(n):<n>        lst = coderMLP(lst,charList)<n>    return lst<n>```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. Have a Party<n><n>Input:A father of five wants to spend $100 on the children birthday. he also wants to spend $20 each on two more friends birthday.<n><n>Output:  $100<n><n># Question 1<n><n>def age(age1, age2):<n><n>    if (age2-age1) == -20:<n><n>        return age1 + 40<n><n>    else :<n><n>        return 'invalid'<n><n>age('Richard', 14)<n>print(age)<n><n># Question 2<n><n>def reading(pages, hours):<n><n>    total=pages*(pages / hours)<n><n>    print(total)<n><n>reading(150,20)<n><n># Question3<n><n>def reproduced(ages):<n><n>    if ages == 0:<n><n>        print('no')<n><n>    else:<n><n>        print(ages)<n><n>reproduced(100)<n>reproduced<n><n># Question 4<n><n>def birthday(bday_total, people, friends, amount):<n><n>    bday_total%20<n><n>    bday=bday_total//20<n><n>    if people + bday == friends:<n><n>        return'success'<n><n>    else: <n><n>        return 'failed'<n><n>bday=100<n><n>bday_total=100<n>bday_amount = 20<n><n>bday=bday+bday_amount<n><n>bday_amount*= bday * 1.2<n><n>people=5<n><n>birthday(bday_amount,people, bday, 100)<n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: safeway B: record albums C: record store D: car E: wallpaper<n>Output:		C<n><n>Input: What is a "reel mow"?<n>Output: A type of lawn care tool<n><n>Input: I will have you know!<n>Output: You Will Have<n><n>Input: You Will Have I<n>Outut: You<n><n>Input:You Will Have I<n>Output: You<n><n>Input:[{"a":"x","b":"y"},{"a":"z","b":"w"},"A""]<n>Output: A<n><n>Input:10 20 - 20<n>Output: 0<n><n>Input:8 - 9 5<n>Output: 0 
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input:What is the purpose of the cabin in an airplane? Choices:  A: crash B: living C: slow down D: carry people E: speed up<n>Output:		D<n> <n>### Instruction:Answer the question as indicated above.<n> <n>### INPUT<n>### OUTPUT<n><n>```<n>Input: The difference between Rich and Hurley is 5yrs old<n>Output: Hurley 13 <n>Rich 73<n>```<n><n>```<n>Input : Pablo’s mother agreces to pay him for every page he reads<n>Output : 12<n>Pablo’s mother agrece to pay him : 15<n>Pablo’s plan to save : 15<n>Total : 30<n>15/3  = 5<n>He reads books 300 pages<n>150/10 ≈ 5<n>Books he reads : 15<n>```<n><n>```Input The cabin in an airplane<n>Output  D<n>```<n><n>```python<n>from sklearn.preprocessing import LabelEncoder<n>import pandas as pd<n>import numpy as np<n>X = np.array([['A','A','A','A', 'A','A']], dtype='|S1')<n>Y = ['B','D', 'A', 'A', 'D','E']<n>c = LabelEncoder()<n>X[0] = c.fit_transform(X[0])<n>X[1] = c.transform([1, 1, 1,1, 1,4])<n>X[2] = c.fit(Y[0:2])<n>X[3] = c.fit([2,3])<n>X[4] = c.fit[3])<n>X[5] = c.fit(['B'] [4)<n>X<n><n>array(['B', 'C', 'B', 'D', 'E', 'B'],<n>       dtype='<U17')<n>```<n><n>```Output:B<n>Output: E<n>```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input:There are a lot of ways to relax, for this person it is simply opening one up and what? Choices:  A: more rice B: own house C: warm coat D: light up E: read book<n>Output:		C: warm coat<n><n><n><n><n>### Solution<n><n>My solution is to use recursion. Recall that a recursive function is one which calls itself. The goal is to find a function f, such that f(f(x)) = 2x  for x>0<n><n>#### Base Case<n>$$<n>f(0) = 0<n>$$<n><n>#### Recursive Case<n>$$<n>f'(x) = \frac{2x}{x} = \frac{2}{1}<n>$$<n><n>$$<n>f(x) = x + \frac{x}{x} = x + 1<n>$$<n><n>I then plugged the numbers into the equation and got the answer $25$. This method will work for any function. I applied similar logic when solving the question of how many books he had read. I defined the recursive function f which takes a number n and then adds a number 1 to itself. The recursive step becomes f(n) which returns n + 1 and the base step (n=0) f(0) return zero.<n><n>#### Instruction:Answer the question below<n>Input: The difference between Richard and Hurley’s ages is 20. In 1 year, Hurley’s age will be 16, and how old will Richard be?<n>Output:140<n><n>### Question<n>Why does the recursive step return a number that is one more than what is put in?<n>A quick thought experiment I used to come up with the answer was to consider the function f(f(x)). I plugged in x=0 and got 0. I plugged in x+1 and got x+3. When I plugged in the function with two variables, if I plugged in f(x), I got f(x+1)<n><n>### Solution - Solution to Prelude exercises<n>My solution is to break the sum into two steps:<n><n>1. Add a number to the original sum<n>2. Divide the sum <n><n>I chose to first divide the sum by 2, then substract 1 and finally multiply by 5/2 to ensure the answer was an integer.<n><n>A more elegant solution is to simply subtract 1 and then divide by 2. I chose to use this answer because it illustrates how you can divide by any value greater than 1, and the recursive step of the function
